entry.title: STORMS BRING HEAVY RAIN, RISING RIVERS, POWER OUTAGES
entry.summary: December 30, 204 4:00 a.m. Storms that started Thursday brought heavy rain, rising rivers, power outages, and more to southern Oregon. Data from the National Weather Service showed 3.08 inches of rain recorded at the Roseburg Regional Airport between Thursday morning and Sunday evening. Forecasters told News Radio 93-9 FM and 1240 KQEN that river...

entry.title: WYDEN REACTS TO PASSING OF FORMER PRESIDENT JIMMY CARTER
entry.summary: December 30, 2024 3:40 a.m. Oregon U.S. Senator Ron Wyden is reacting to the passing for former President Jimmy Carter on Sunday. Wyden said, “President Carter embodied what it means to be a public servant in both elected office and in his personal life by working to make our country and world a more...

entry.title: ADAPT ANNOUNCES ANNUAL CLOSURE FOR NEW YEARS DAY
entry.summary: December 30, 2024 3:30 a.m. Adapt Integrated Health Care will be closed for all non-crisis, non-residential services and sites in Douglas, Coos, Curry and Josephine counties on Wednesday January 1st for New Year’s Day. This will be a full-day closure with services resuming on Thursday January 2nd. 24/7 Crisis Support Services will continue operations as...

entry.title: MYRTLE CREEK ANNOUNCES PUBLIC MEETINGS FOR JANUARY
entry.summary: December 30, 2024 3:20 a.m. The City of Myrtle Creek has announced its public meetings for January: *The city council will meet January 7th and January 21st at 5:30 p.m. *The code review board meets January 13th and January 27th at 5:00 p.m. *The park commission will meet January 14th at 5:30 p.m. *The urban...

entry.title: ROSEBURG DISPOSAL COLLECTING CHRISTMAS TREES
entry.summary: December 30, 2024 3:05 a.m. Roseburg Disposal is collecting Christmas trees for free with dumpsters located around the Roseburg area. Only real trees will be accepted. No artificial trees, lights, ornaments, flocking, tinsel, trash or tree stands should be dropped off. Trees will be turned into clean mulch. Collection dumpsters are located at: *Legion Field...

entry.title: FESTIVAL OF LIGHTS CONTINUES THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING
entry.summary: The Umpqua Valley Festival of Lights continues through Wednesday evening. Presented by the Roseburg Rotary Club, the 32nd annual event features over 500,000 lights and 90 displays at River Forks Park, northwest of Roseburg. This year, there were a number of upgrades including a new 20-foot replica of the Umpqua Lighthouse and restoration work on...

entry.title: BLM CALL FOR APPLICATIONS: ARTIST IN RESIDENCE PROGRAM
entry.summary: December 30, 2024 2:50 a.m. The Bureau of Land Management has issued a call for applications for its Artist-in- Residence program at the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument. The selected artist receives a one-to two-week residency at CSNM in the month of June. Selected artists will create work while immersed in a beautiful environment and share their...

entry.title: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT THROUGH 7:00 A.M. SUNDAY FOR SOUTHERN OREGON
entry.summary: December 29, 2024 5:50 a.m. The National Weather Service has issued a Flood Warning for much of southern Oregon through 7:00 a.m. Sunday. Forecasters at the National Weather Service in Medford said urban area and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. The Warning area includes Douglas, Jackson, Josephine, Coos, and Curry counties....

entry.title: FLOOD WARNING FOR DEER CREEK AT ROSEBURG
entry.summary: December 29, 2024 5:40 a.m. A Flood Warning is in effect through Sunday evening for Deer Creek at Roseburg. The National Weather Service said at 9:00 p.m. Saturday the stage was 6.7 feet. Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. Deer Creek is forecast to reach 11.6 feet late Sunday morning. It will then fall below flood...

entry.title: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY FOR MOUNTAIN AREAS
entry.summary: December 28, 2024 4:40 p.m. A Winter Weather Advisory is in effect from 4:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. Sunday for mountain areas in parts of southern Oregon. Forecasters at the National Weather Service said snow is expected. Total snow accumulations between 8 and 12 inches are forecast. Winds will gust as high as 55 miles...

entry.title: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON
entry.summary: December 28, 2024 4: 3o p.m. A Flood Watch remains in effect through Sunday afternoon at 4:00 p.m. for much of southern Oregon. Forecasters at the National Weather Service said flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. The Watch area includes central Douglas County and its eastern foothills, Josephine and Jackson County, and...

entry.title: FLOOD WATCH CONTINUES FOR DEER CREEK AT ROSEBURG
entry.summary: December 28, 2024 4:00 p.m. A Flood Watch remains in effect until early Tuesday afternoon for Deer Creek at Roseburg. Forecasters at the National Weather Service said flooding is possible. As of 1:00 p.m. the stage was at 5.7 feet. Flood stage is 10.0 feet and may be reached later Saturday night. entry.title: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT SATURDAY MORNING THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT STARTING AT 10:00 A.M. SATURDAY FOR MUCH OF SOUTHERN OREGON

entry.title: FLOOD WATCH ISSUED FOR DEER CREEK UNTIL TUESDAY
entry.summary: December 27, 2024 2:40 p.m. A Flood Watch is in effect until early Tuesday afternoon for Deer Creek at Roseburg. The National Weather Service said minor flooding is possible due to excessive rainfall. At 11.5 feet, water will begin to cover Southeast Douglas Avenue west of Dawson Road. Flood stage is 10.0 feet. entry.title: INSIDE DOUGLAS COUNTY 12.27.24
entry.summary: Douglas County Commissioner Tom Kress talks about funding for roads in the county, on this encore program from October 16th.

entry.title: 2024 News-Review Sports Top 10: No. 10, state track & field champions
entry.summary: Reedsport junior Clayton Wilson was a double winner in the OSAA Class 2A boys state track and field meet at Hayward Field in May, winning the 3,000 meters with a time of 8:59.58 (PR) and taking first in the 1,500…

entry.title: 51 Years of the Endangered Species Act: Legacy, Controversies and Oregon's Timber Wars
entry.summary: Just days after Christmas in 1973 President Richard Nixon signed into law the Endangered Species Act, establishing one of the strongest conservation laws in history.
